that's because "sudo apt-get" *is* the good, safe and reasonable way to install programs.
yes I like apt-get very much:) But there is a program that doesnt work through that installation method; Tor
you're kidding? tor is available from universe, and it'll even install privoxy and get configured to work with it
!info tor > tholme
when it is installed it says that Im not the correct user. It says that the user should be 'debian-tor'
[warn]  /var/lib/tor is not owned by this user (tholme, 1000) but by debian-tor (112). Perhaps you are running Tor as the wrong user?
Apr 27 18:38:26.941 [warn]  Failed to parse/validate config: Couldn't access/create private data directory "/var/lib/tor"
it didn't do that for me on edgy, but that doesn't seem like a good reason for not installing something like that (a *service*, not even an application!) manually...
how are you trying to start tor?
I installed it, and typed 'tor'

bad idea... tor is a service, you're not supposed to just run the program. type  sudo invoke-rc.d tor start  (which will probably tell it it's already started, since it normally gets auto-started on installation and on boot)
trying it now
Raising maximum number of filedescriptors (ulimit -n) to 8192.
Starting tor daemon: tor...
done.

it started. you should now be able to connect apps to it. you probably want to also do  sudo invoke-rc.d privoxy start , in order to point proxy-able apps (like web browser) to privoxy (which will then use tor)
Never heard of those commands...lol
Need to do some reading I think
they work for all services.  sudo invoke-rc.d <servicename> start|stop|restart . do  ls /etc/init.d  to see all the services you have currently available (but don't try stopping random ones ;)
